Package org.firstinspires.ftc.teamcode

Class RobotHardware

java.lang.Object
org.firstinspires.ftc.teamcode.RobotHardware
public class RobotHardware extends Object
Instead of each Op Mode class redefining the robot's hardware resources within its implementation, This RobotHardware class has a given robot's component resources defined and set up all in one place. It also has convenience methods like driveRobot(), setArmPower(), setHandPosition(), etc. that work for that robot. Where possible, the actual hardware objects are "abstracted" (or hidden) so the OpMode code just makes calls into the class, rather than accessing the internal hardware directly. This is why the objects are declared "private".

    • autoDriveRobot

      public void autoDriveRobot(int leftInches, int rightInches, double speed)
      Drive robot to the targeted position designated by the passed leftInches and rightInches, at the power specified by speed.
      Parameters:
      leftInches - How far the left wheels should travel
      rightInches - How far the right wheels should travel
      speed - speed applied to all wheels

    • autoDriveRobot

      public void autoDriveRobot(int leftInches, int rightInches)
      autoDriveRobot using DEFAULT_WHEEL_MOTOR_SPEED.
      Parameters:
      leftInches - How far the left wheels should travel
      rightInches - How far the right wheels should travel

    • autoDriveRobotWithHeading

      public void autoDriveRobotWithHeading(int inches, double heading, double speed)
      Drive robot the targeted inches, at the passed heading, at the passed speed. Left and right wheel speeds are adjusted as necessary to get the robot on the passed heading.
      Parameters:
      inches - How far the robot should travel
      heading - Heading in yaw degree (+/- 180)
      speed - Speed to apply to all wheels

    • turnToHeading

      public void turnToHeading(double heading, double speed)
      Spin on the central axis to point in a new direction. Move will stop if either of these conditions occur: 1) Move gets to the heading (angle) 2) Driver stops the OpMode running.
      Parameters:
      heading - Absolute Heading Angle (in Degrees) relative to last gyro reset. If a relative angle is required, add/subtract from current heading.
      speed - Desired speed of turn. (range 0 to +1.0)

    • getHeadingCorrection

      public double getHeadingCorrection(double desiredHeading, double gainFactor)
      Calculate a motor speed that can be used to turn the robot to the desiredHeading. Get the difference between the passed desiredHeading and the actual heading. Normalize the difference to be in terms of yaw (+/- 180 degrees). Multiply the difference by gainFactor to get a motor speed (which will never be > 1 or < -1).
      Parameters:
      desiredHeading - yaw degrees (+/- 180)
      gainFactor - factor to convert heading difference to a motor speed
      Returns:
      motor speed in the range of -1 to 1.

    • setRunModeForAllWheels

      public void setRunModeForAllWheels(com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.DcMotor.RunMode runMode)
      Set the RunMode for all wheel motors to the passed runMode.
      Parameters:
      runMode - DcMotor.RunMode

    • setPowerAllWheels

      public void setPowerAllWheels(double speed, double headingSpeedAdjustment)
      Adjust the left and right motor speeds by the passed headingSpeedAdjustment, then set power to the left and right wheels to those powers. For example, setPowerAllWheels(.4, .6) sets the left motors to -.2 and the right motors to 1.
      Parameters:
      speed - - power of the motor, a value in the interval [-1.0, 1.0]
      headingSpeedAdjustment - - yaw in degrees (+/- 180)

    • setPowerAllWheels

      public void setPowerAllWheels(double speed)
      Set the Power for all wheels to the passed speed.
      Parameters:
      speed - - power of the motor, a value in the interval [-1.0, 1.0]

      Parameters:
      stick1X - Value from stick 1's X axis
      stick1Y - Value from stick 1's Y axis
      stick2X - Value from stick 2's X axis

      public static boolean isWithinTolerance(double expectedValue, double actualValue, double tolerance)
      Returns true if the passed expectedValue is within tolerance of the passed actualValue. Otherwise it returns false. For example, if the expectedValue is 10, the actualValue is 11, and tolerance is 2, then true will be returned.
      Parameters:
      expectedValue -
      actualValue -
      tolerance -
      Returns:

      colorThreshold -

    • getSpikeObjectPosition

      public int getSpikeObjectPosition()
      Determine which position (1, 2, or 3) the sensor detects an object (such as a cube) is in. In this example, if neither the left or right sensors detect an object, the position is 2. If the left sensor detects an object, the position is 1. Lastly, if the right sensor detects an object, the position is 3.
      Returns:
      int positionNumber

    • getPotentiometerVoltage

      public double getPotentiometerVoltage()
      Return potentiometer's current voltage.
      Returns:
      voltage

    • getPotentiometerAngle

      public double getPotentiometerAngle(double voltage)
      Return calculated angle corresponding to a passed voltage. Example: If the potentiometer's maximum voltage is 3.3, and it's maximum angle is 270 degrees, and the passed voltage is 1.65 then the angle is 1.65 * 270 / 3.3 = 135 degrees.
      Returns:
      angle

    • getPotentiometerAngle

      public double getPotentiometerAngle()
      Return calculated angle corresponding to potentiometer's current voltage. Example: If the potentiometer's maximum voltage is 3.3, and it's maximum angle is 270 degrees, and the current voltage is 1.65 then the current angle is 1.65 * 270 / 3.3 = 135 degrees.
      Returns:
      angle
